Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Expert and Novice Graphical Communication Through Digital Sketching

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to communicate through graphical means such as sketching is central to engineering education and practice, yet little is known about how, why, and when students use engineering sketches or how they learn to use them. This project studies how novices and experts produce and respond to their own sketches, and builds on existing techniques for digital sketch recognition. Students' representational fluency will be examined by exploring the similarities and distinctions between experts and novices in their use and production of engineering sketches during problem solving by focusing on sketching in two domains: digital logic and trusses. These domains use complementary styles of sketches as digital logic sketches are visually distinct from real-world implementations, and trusses rely on facsimiles of real-world objects. The use of complementary domains will provide richer observations that can inform the future development of theory and pedagogical tools. Educational data mining of students' sketches will provide new observations on sketching behaviors (e.g., pen speed, pressure) that might be obscured or invisible to human researchers.

Think-aloud interviews will be conducted as students and graduate teaching assistants solve analysis and design problems for digital logic and trusses. Data from these interviews will be analyzed with qualitative analysis techniques to categorize behaviors of novices and experts. Additionally, preliminary data mining will be performed on digital pen inputs to identify salient variables that can be detected algorithmically. The intellectual merit of this project is established by its basis on a rich tradition in the study of expert-novice differences. This project is particularly informed by prior research on how novices and experts comprehend and use static images in their reasoning. Aligning educational data mining with qualitative analysis of sketching will inform the development of a new form of mixed methods research, advancing the state of the art in educational research methods. The broader impacts of this project will be seen through three different facets: i) providing new avenues for richer credentialing in engineering education, ii) enhancing and maximizing the effectiveness of pedagogies and their tools through data mining, and iii) producing a large corpus of sketching, simultaneously building a developer/user community that can use that database.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering intensely relies on the use of visual representations. For example, the sample representation might help an engineer determine whether a flagpole would break given an amount of wind blowing against it. These visual representations make invisible phenomenon and processes accessible to engineers as they solve complex problems. Although these visual representations are critical for learning engineering and solving engineering problems, we have historically known little about how these representations help or hinder students? learning. In this project, we recorded students as they solved engineering problems in mechanical engineering and computer engineering. We then analyzed these interviews to document ways in which students struggled to use visual representations when solving engineering problems and to document how these visual representations may make it more difficult for students to learn important concepts. From these interviews, we identified four patterns in the ways that students interact with visual representations during problem solving. 

First, students instinctively search for parts of a visual representation that they think are relevant to their problem-solving task. Once they identify these parts, they engage in quick and easy problem-solving patterns that save them time and energy. The main difference between expert and novice students was that the expert students did a better job of identifying which parts of the visual representation were actually important for solving the problem. For example, in the sample representation, all students readily notice the arrows on the pole to be important but only the more expert students noticed that the intersection of the pole with the ground was the most important part of the visual representation. If we are designing a flag pole, we want to make sure that that pole does not fall over! The interaction of the pole with the ground is what keeps the pole from moving, which ultimately is the source of forces that could break the pole. Our remaining findings focused on identifying what aspects of the visual representations seemed to mislead students? attention and learning. 

Second, students struggled to use visual representations when conceptually important parts of diagrams were visually obscure. For example, the intersection of the pole with the ground is visually uninteresting but critically important. Third, students inappropriately conceived of distinct concepts as the same when the symbols or figures used to represent them were similar. For example, ?force? and ?shear force? are distinct concepts represented with the symbols ?F? and ?V,? respectively, while ?moment? and ?bending moment? are distinct concepts represented with the symbols ?M? and ?M.? Students struggled to maintain conceptual distinctions of ?moment? and ?bending moment? more than ?force? and ?shear force,? we believe in part because of the lack of distinct symbols for ?moment? and ?bending moment.? Fourth, some visual representations may not provide all information needed to solve a problem. Students may not recognize that information is missing and then derive incorrect or incomplete solutions.

Based on these findings, we experimented with modifying some traditional representations to see whether we could help students better solve problems or more quickly learn critical concepts. For example, we added an extra red symbol onto the flag pole representation to help students recognize the critical concept that the intersection keeps the pole from moving. Our experiments suggested that modifying diagrams in this way helped students more quickly learn about the importance of this intersection, even after the modified diagrams were taken away.

Intellectual Merit: This project was built on a rich tradition in the study of expert-novice differences. This project is particularly informed by prior research on how novices and experts comprehend and use visual representations in their reasoning. We expand on this research, filling a gap in our understanding, by studying how novices and experts produce and respond to their own sketches. Our study also paired qualitative and quantitative research methods to develop a richer understanding of how students use visual representations while also testing the potential usefulness of these findings in the classroom.

Broader Impact: Our project focused on identifying ways to help instructors better use visual representations to help students learn and for assessing how well students learn to use those representations. Our project identified low-cost, easily shared interventions that instructors can use to help students learn. These interventions can help make engineering and STEM education more accessible for a wide range of students.
